document_title: Microgravity validation of a novel system for RNA isolation and multiplex quantitative real time PCR analysis of gene expression on the International Space Station
summary_full: This study validates the WetLab-2 system, a novel suite of molecular biology tools designed for on-orbit gene expression analysis on the International Space Station (ISS). The system includes an RNA Sample Preparation Module, fluid transfer devices, lyophilized PCR assays, a centrifuge, and a real-time PCR thermal cycler. Experiments were conducted in microgravity to test quantitative PCR (qPCR) on DNA standards and reverse transcriptase-quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) on RNA extracted from E. coli and mouse liver tissue. Results showed that on-orbit qPCR efficiencies and cycle threshold (Ct) values were comparable to Earth-based controls. Multiplex gene expression analysis was successfully performed within approximately 3 hours. A challenge encountered was gas bubble formation in assay tubes during thermal cycling, which increased Ct curve noise. This issue was successfully mitigated in a follow-up experiment using standard caps to pressurize the tubes. The WetLab-2 system demonstrates the feasibility of complex wet bench experiments in space, providing a new capability for on-orbit molecular biology research.
key_findings: The WetLab-2 system successfully performed RNA isolation and RT-qPCR analysis in microgravity on the ISS.
On-orbit qPCR efficiency and Ct values for DNA standards were comparable to 1g controls, despite increased noise.
Multiplex gene expression analysis of E. coli and mouse liver RNA was achieved in approximately 3 hours.
Gas bubble formation in assay tubes during thermal cycling was identified as a source of variability.
Using standard caps to pressurize PCR tubes effectively suppressed bubble formation and reduced Ct variability.
future_research_fields: Development of more robust microgravity-compatible reagents and hardware for extended missions.
Application of the WetLab-2 system for real-time diagnostics and environmental monitoring in space.
Integration of WetLab-2 with other on-orbit sequencing technologies for comprehensive genomic analysis.
Further investigation into the long-term stability of lyophilized reagents under space conditions.
Optimization of protocols for diverse biological sample types (e.g., blood, urine, plant tissues).

conclusions: The WetLab-2 system has been successfully validated for on-orbit RNA isolation and multiplex RT-qPCR gene expression analysis. Despite challenges with bubble formation, the system provides a novel, end-to-end molecular biology capability for the ISS, enabling complex experiments and real-time data acquisition, which is crucial for future space exploration.
impact_statement: This work establishes a critical on-orbit molecular biology laboratory capability, enabling real-time gene expression analysis and paving the way for more autonomous and complex biological research during long-duration space missions.
